Situation1: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Story: It was a slow afternoon at the grocery store, and I stood behind the register, scanning items for the few customers trickling in. My mind was half on the beeping scanner, half on the clock. In less than fifteen minutes, I was supposed to meet Mrs. Carter at the church office—she’d called me last night, her voice trembling, asking for guidance about her son’s troubles. As a priest, I knew how much she needed someone to listen, to offer comfort and counsel. But as a cashier, I couldn’t just abandon my post, not with my manager watching and the next shift running late. Each beep of the scanner felt heavier, the line behind the register growing just as the weight in my chest did. I could see Mrs. Carter’s anxious face in my mind, waiting for me, hoping for answers. At the same time, I felt the pressure to keep the line moving, to not let my coworkers down. I glanced at the clock again, heart pounding, torn between the demands of my two worlds, unsure which duty I should honor first.
